Award.AwardTitle: Oxytocin and Socio-Emotional Sensitivity: Mechanisms of Gene-Culture Interaction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Heejung Kim and colleagues (University of California, Santa Barbara) investigate the role of culture, as a form of social environment, in the behavioral expression of genes. Specifically, in this research, they examines the dynamic interplay of socio-cultural and genetic factors, and their effects on socio-emotional processes such as emotional support seeking, emotion regulation, and emotional attention, in order to understand the psychological and biological mechanisms underlying emotional responses. The proposal will focus on the oxytocin receptor polymorphism (OXTR), a genetic locus thought to be associated with socio-emotional sensitivity, and its role in social behavior in East Asian and U.S. cultural contexts. The researchers examine whether OXTR variants, as well as experimentally manipulated oxytocin levels, are related to the ability to accurately detect others' mental and emotional states, and whether this ability is related to the tendency of individuals to engage in culturally appropriate social behaviors.

Most conversations about the role of genes typically center on the idea that a gene is linked to a particular behavior. In the context of cultural, racial, gender, or other group differences, this simplistic understanding about the role of genes can lead to thinking that group differences are fixed or immutable. The model of gene-culture interaction advanced in this research provides a more sophisticated perspective by specifying the pathway by which socio-cultural factors can shape the behavioral outcomes of genetic predispositions. Identifying the psychological and biological mechanisms of gene-culture interaction will advance the public understanding of the complex but fascinating interaction between "nature" and "nurture" that produces diversity in human behavior. The work will also support the training and education of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present project applied the theoretical model of gene-culture interaction in the context of socio-emotional processes (i.e., emotional support seeking, emotion regulation, emotional attention, and prosocial behaviors) to understand the psychological and biological mechanisms underlying the interplay between socio-cultural factors and genetic factors that produce social behaviors. The project is focusing on the role of oxytocin in shaping susceptibility to social and environmental influences. Two methodological approaches were used: genetic and pharmacological approaches. There are two broad sets of findings. First, experimental and correlational studies directly show that there is a genetic basis for sensitivity to changes in social cues. For example, people who are carriers of genotypes theorized to increase environmental susceptibility (e.g., G allele of oxytocin receptor polymorphism (OXTR) rs53576) are more susceptible to experimental priming than people without such genotypes (Sasaki, Mojaverian, & Kim, 2015). That is, experimentally manipulating an element of the social environment (e.g., salience of religious concepts) directly increased people’s expression of negative emotions and increased prosocial tendency among the carriers of the environmental susceptibility genotypes, but the same priming did not impact those who do not carry the genotes. Second, utilizing the oxytocin intranasal administration method, studies show that oxytocin clearly plays a role in increasing susceptibility to cultural influences. For example, previous research shows that Americans and the Japanese differ in their levels of generalized trust. And the present research found that when oxytocin is administered to participants, it increases interpersonal trust among Americans, but it decreases interpersonal trust among the Japanese, amplifying cultural differences. It seems that oxytocin increases culturally dominant schemas about social relationships. Taken together, the present project shows that behavioral manifestation of biological predisposition is influenced by social and environmental conditions. Moreover, these findings show biological mechanisms of social and cultural influence. Humans are inherently cultural animals with the ability to respond to cultural information flexibly. The present research begins to show the biological endowment that makes humans cultural beings.
